item.title: Seeing AI Through the Curry‚ÄìHoward Lens
item.description:
The Curry‚ÄìHoward correspondence draws a deep equivalence between logic and computation: propositions as types, proofs as programs. It’s an elegant insight from the 1960s‚Äîand surprisingly relevant to where AI is headed.

Many researchers have explored formal verification, type-driven development, and reasoning-based generation in AI. But Curry‚ÄìHoward offers something more: a conceptual framework for understanding what’s missing in current LLMs and what becomes possible if we push further.

The gap is narrowing. We’re already seeing glimpses of this future: reasoning models that decompose problems step-by-step, agents that iterate and verify their outputs, post-training techniques that reward logical consistency over mere plausibility. But these are still fundamentally pattern-matching systems with reasoning-like behavior grafted on. Curry‚ÄìHoward suggests a more fundamental shift‚Äîone where programs are proofs and types are logical propositions about correctness.

What would the next leap look like?

Programs as proofs in scientific computing. Imagine an LLM generating not just a quantum circuit in Qiskit, but a circuit with accompanying correctness guarantees‚Äîproving it implements the intended algorithm, respects hardware constraints, or satisfies specific properties. In science and quantum computing, this means code we can trust, not just code that runs and passes tests.

Types as reasoning scaffolds. Dependently-typed languages like Coq or Lean already embody Curry‚ÄìHoward: types express logical specifications, and programs that type-check are valid proofs. Current LLMs can generate code in these languages, but they don’t truly reason within them. The next generation should navigate proof spaces natively, generating solutions that are provably correct by construction, not by post-hoc verification.

AI as a verification partner. In quantum computing, bugs aren’t just inconvenient‚Äîthey’re catastrophic. A misconfigured gate sequence, an incorrect assumption about decoherence, and months of experimental time are wasted. Today’s coding agents can catch some errors through testing and iteration. Tomorrow’s should provide formal guarantees.

The challenge ahead

The challenge is architectural: current approaches layer reasoning on top of statistical foundations. What we need are systems where formal reasoning is intrinsic‚Äîmodels that learn not just to predict tokens, but to construct and verify proofs, where the training objective itself rewards logical soundness.

This isn’t distant future. Research on neural theorem proving, program synthesis with specifications, and LLMs integrated with proof assistants is accelerating. What Curry‚ÄìHoward offers is a north star: a vision of AI that doesn’t just mimic reasoning, but embodies it.

For fields like quantum computing, and science in general, where correctness is non-negotiable, this evolution from reasoning-flavored generation to proof-native systems could be transformative.

Note: The featured image for this post was generated using Gemini Nano Banana.

item.title: Qiskit Code Assistant Upgraded to Mistral-Small-3.2-24B-Qiskit
item.description:
We’ve upgraded the Qiskit Code Assistant! üöÄ

Last month, we introduced mistral-small-3.2-24b-qiskit, replacing granite-3.3-8b-qiskit.

Key Improvements

‚úÖ Better accuracy: The new model ranks higher across key benchmarks, including QiskitHumanEval, QiskitHumanEval Hard, HumanEval, MathQA, ASDiv, SciQ and others (see the model card for more info).

‚úÖ Improved UX: More precise responses for quantum programming tasks.

‚úÖ Open access: Available on Hugging Face ‚Üí https://huggingface.co/Qiskit/mistral-small-3.2-24b-qiskit.

This update is part of our mission to make quantum development more intuitive and efficient. üåü

Explore it, test it, and share your feedback!

#Qiskit #QuantumComputing #AI #OpenSource #HuggingFace

Originally shared on LinkedIn on November 27, 2025

item.title: AI for Qiskit. Hackathon starter pack
Quantum Verifiable Rewards for Post-Training Qiskit Code Assistant
item.description:
üìÑ We just released a new paper “Quantum Verifiable Rewards for Post-Training Qiskit Code Assistant” - and it’s been getting great attention from folks in the quantum field since day one. üéâ

üîç What we built: A novel approach to train AI models that can write better quantum code using Qiskit. What makes this interesting:

‚úÖ Quantum verification at the core - Instead of just hoping the AI-generated code works, we actually verify it runs correctly on real quantum systems ‚úÖ Smart training pipeline - We created synthetic quantum problem-test pairs and used both Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) and Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to align our models ‚úÖ Real quantum feedback - Our models learn directly from quantum hardware and systems rewards, ensuring the code they generate actually works in practice

The results: Our best model significantly outperforms existing leading open-source baselines on the challenging Qiskit-HumanEval-hard benchmark.

This work presents a solid contribution to making quantum programming more accessible through AI assistance. The approach of using quantum hardware verification to train coding assistants opens up promising directions for future research.

Proud of our team’s thoughtful work on this project: Nicolas Dupuis, Adarsh Tiwari, Youssef MROUEH, David Kremer, Ismael Faro. The intersection of AI and quantum computing continues to offer compelling research opportunities.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2508.20907

#QuantumComputing #AI #MachineLearning #Qiskit #Research #AIforQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on August 30, 2025 - 76 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Qiskit Code Assistant: New Open-Source LLM Models Released
item.description:
üöÄ We’re thrilled to announce the latest open-source LLM releases from the Qiskit Code Assistant team! üöÄ

These new models bring enhanced capabilities and broader compatibility to quantum computing development.

What’s New:

‚ú® Qiskit 2.0 Compatibility - Our newer models are fully compatible with Qiskit 2.0 code, ensuring seamless development with the latest quantum computing framework

üß† Enhanced Text Understanding - Significant improvements in general text comprehension and code generation capabilities

üî¨ Expanding Our Horizons - We continue to leverage the newest stable versions of IBM Granite 3.2 and 3.3 models, while for the first time exploring beyond IBM Granite with the powerful Qwen2.5-Coder series

Available Models: ‚Ä¢ Granite 3.3 8B Qiskit (+ GGUF) ‚Ä¢ Granite 3.2 8B Qiskit (+ GGUF) ‚Ä¢ Qwen2.5-Coder 14B Qiskit (+ GGUF)

All models are available on Hugging Face and ready for local deployment!

üîó Browse All Models: https://huggingface.co/Qiskit üîó Get Started: https://quantum.cloud.ibm.com/docs/en/guides/qiskit-code-assistant-local

We’d love to hear how you’re making the most of these models! Share your experiences and quantum development journey with us. üåü

Big thanks to the team involved in this release, specially to Nicolas Dupuis, Adarsh Tiwari and Ismael Faro

#QuantumComputing #OpenSource #AI #LLMs #Qiskit #IBM #TechInnovation #QuantumDevelopment #QiskitCodeAssistant

Originally shared on LinkedIn on July 8, 2025 - 304 reactions, 16 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Among IBM Giants and Pioneers: Reflections from IBM Tech 2025 in Singapore
item.description:
Among üëÅÔ∏èüêù‚ìÇÔ∏è Giants and Pioneers: Reflections from IBM Tech 2025 in Singapore üá∏üá¨

I had the privilege of attending IBM Tech 2025 in Singapore this week - an exclusive, invitation-only gathering of IBM’s top technical talent from around the world. As one of the selected participants, I’m humbled to have been recognized among IBM’s most innovative and performing technical minds.

The atmosphere was electric as we dove deep into the future of AI, quantum computing, and emerging technologies. What struck me most was not just the cutting-edge content of the presentations from colleagues and leaders such as Ruchir Puri, Suja Viswesan, Ric Lewis, Borja Peropadre, and others, but the quality of conversations happening between sessions. Exchanging ideas with brilliant colleagues across different technical disciplines provided invaluable perspective on where technology is headed.

Particularly enlightening were the discussions with my IBM Quantum and AI Research colleagues and the cross-pollination of ideas between different technical domains. These connections reinforced my belief that the most transformative innovations happen at the intersection of diverse expertise.

Beyond the technical exchanges, Singapore provided a stunning backdrop for cultural experiences that complemented our professional activities. The city’s blend of tradition and futuristic vision perfectly mirrored our discussions about building tomorrow’s technologies while honoring established principles.

Returning home energized and inspired, I’m grateful for both the recognition and the opportunity to contribute to IBM’s technical community. The future belongs to those who collaborate across boundaries, and IBM Tech 2025 demonstrated that our collective expertise is our greatest strength.

#IBMTech2025 #Innovation #TechnicalExcellence #QuantumComputing #AI #FutureTech #IBMLife #AIforQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on March 28, 2025 - 96 reactions, 14 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.description:

item.title: Shipping Granite-8B-Qiskit-RC-0.10: The Final Model of Current Training Era
item.description:
üöÄ Last Friday, we shipped something special: granite-8b-qiskit-rc-0.10, our latest revision of the LLMs that empower the Qiskit Code Assistant.

Trained on a significantly expanded Qiskit synthetic dataset, this release marks the end of an era - it’s our final model using the current training approach.

What’s next? We’re pivoting to newer Granite base models and starting to integrate other cutting-edge techniques. Stay tuned!

Check it out: https://huggingface.co/Qiskit/granite-8b-qiskit-rc-0.10

#Qiskit #QuantumComputing #AI #AIforQuantum #QiskitCodeAssistant

Originally shared on LinkedIn on February 18, 2025 - 126 reactions, 8 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Quantum Developer Conference 2024: Showcasing AI-Powered Quantum Tools
item.description:
Excited to be participating in the Quantum Developer Conference 2024 at the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center! It’s been fantastic networking with fellow quantum computing professionals and showcasing the latest developments at the intersection of AI and quantum computing.

We’re featuring exciting innovations including the Qiskit Code Assistant and our cutting-edge AI-powered transpiler passes. These tools represent significant steps forward in making quantum computing more accessible and efficient.

Learn more: https://www.ibm.com/quantum/blog/qdc-2024

#QuantumComputing #AI #IBMQuantum #AIforQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on November 15, 2024 - 97 reactions, 1 comment as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Introducing Qiskit Code Assistant: New Blog Post Published
item.description:
Last week we published a blog post summarizing what is the Qiskit Code Assistant and how you can start to use it.

Following the recent launch, users are already leveraging the tool’s features. We’re actively developing improved models with enhanced capabilities that we’re planning to release as open source!
